          "parent_id": "971a1d3f-d487-4e08-84e3-ba48cf125cbe",
          "parent_table": "block",
          "properties": {
            "title": [
              ["Moreover, in Ruby < 2.0, it was very common to add an "],
              ["Hash", [["c"]]],
              [
                " at the end of a method definition to use for optional arguments. The syntax is very similar to keyword arguments, to the point where optional arguments via "
              ],
              ["Hash", [["c"]]],
              [" are compatible with Ruby 2 keyword arguments."]
            ]
          },
          "space_id": "cf9fa7dd-b245-42a0-b929-d5a276b3afe0",
          "type": "text",
          "version": 1
        }
      },
      "ad8ee40d-5aa4-44f0-ac91-25aabb920935": {

            "title": [
              [
                "def say(message, before: \"<p>\", after: \"</p>\")\n  puts \"#{before}#{message}#{after}\"\nend\n\nsay \"Hello World\", before: \"<span>\", after: \"</span>\"\n# => \"<span>Hello World</span>\""
              ]
            ]
          },
          "space_id": "cf9fa7dd-b245-42a0-b929-d5a276b3afe0",

            "title": [
              [
                "def say(message, options = {})\n  before = option.fetch(:before, \"<p>\")\n  after  = option.fetch(:after, \"</p>\")\n  puts \"#{before}#{message}#{after}\"\nend\n\n# The method call is syntactically equivalent to the keyword argument one\nsay \"Hello World\", before: \"<span>\", after: \"</span>\"\n# => \"<span>Hello World</span>\""
              ]
            ]
          },
          "space_id": "cf9fa7dd-b245-42a0-b929-d5a276b3afe0",
          "type": "code",
          "version": 1
        }
      },
